awd_titl_txt: RUI: Investigating Extragalactic Gamma Ray Propagation
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation.  Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe and can be used to test fundamental physics. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is designed to perform high-sensitivity pointed observations of both galactic and extragalactic sources.  This award supports scientists at California State University East Bay (CSUEB) in their work on VERITAS.  Dr. Furniss and her group will analyze VERITAS data to study high-energy gamma-ray emitting galaxies and probe the extragalactic magnetic fields that permeate the Universe.  This project will directly engage undergraduates in particle astrophysics research.  Students involved in the project will visit the VERITAS observatory and contribute to on-site operations and data collection.

The CSUEB group will collect and utilize VERITAS observations of very high-energy emitting active galaxies to study extragalactic gamma-ray photon propagation.  The group will contribute to the first VERITAS extragalactic catalog of these sources.  The isotropy of gamma-ray galaxies will be tested, and the location of the sources with respect to the integrated mass density along the source lines-of-sight will be characterized using publicly available catalogs.  A theoretical connection between the extragalactic magnetic fields along the lines of sight to detected sources will be investigated through the use of simulations of extragalactic gamma-ray initiated cascades.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goals of the project were to explore the possible connection between gamma-ray light seen from extreme galaxies and the strength of the magnetic field between Earth and these objects.  In working toward the goal, this project allowed the collection of gamma-ray data using VERITAS, an imaging atmospheric Cherenkov telescope located south of Tucson, Arizona.  These data, collected and analyzed by undergraduate physics, computer science and computer engineering students from California State University East Bay, allowed us to investigate if the gamma-ray emitting galaxies are located evenly throughout the cosmos, or instead are located in some relation to grand structure, e.g. void space.

One of the immediate results of this work was the collection of VERITAS data on gamma-ray galaxies, motivated by the uncertainty that surrounds where and how this gamma-ray light is made in these extreme objects.  Gamma-ray emitting galaxies are some of the most energetic sources in the universe.  The gamma-ray light from these sources can be affected by light and magnetic fields that reside between Earth and these sources.  The amount of this interaction remains an unknown since the amount of light and the strength of the magnetic fields remain uncertain.  What is known, is that the gamma-ray interaction with the intervening light and magnetic fields decreases the overall observed gamma-ray light as compared to what the galaxy released.  

This project supported the detailed investigation of gamma-ray galaxies, attempting to characterize the density of baryonic matter along the path to the galaxies.  In order to complete the much larger project goal, various smaller steps were necessary, where some of the activities were completed in parallel.  A significant impact of the proposal was that these smaller projects were lead by undergraduate students, who were able to share their results with the public, and partake in peer-peer mentorship through the high impact teaching practice of hands-on learning.

One undergraduate, Tibor Svraka, stated after his shift at the VERITAS Observatory, "VERITAS was the coolest research experience I've ever had, and I'm not just saying that because everyone working on it is cool. I think that the questions that arise from these blazars are fascinating because we still know so little, yet this project is dedicated to figuring out the questions step by step. It was fun to see physicists solve problems when the software was malfunctioning, or when hardware was acting up because it showed me that the greatest skill to learn is the ability to think about ways to solve a problem."

In addition to collecting and analyzing gamma-ray data from galaxies with VERITAS, undergraduate students contributed to an effort to improve the efficiency of VERITAS triggered observations in the case that a gamma-ray galaxy underwent a bright flaring of light.  This effort required the processing of very large datasets through the development of automated data analysis and triggering scripts.   

At the same time as VERITAS observations and analysis were being completed, the gamma-ray catalogs (TeVCat and the Fermi hard source lists) were analyzed and statistically tested for source isotropy, where initial results show that the spatial separation of the sources on the sky are consistent with random distribution not dependent on large scale structure.

Still under investigation is the path density characterization to all sources falling within the footprint of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, being tested against the publicly available void catalogs.   The results so far have prompted more detailed studies, but there is indication that what gamma-ray emission we see from these galaxies may have to do with where they lie in the universal filamentary and void space structure, as well as how brightly they shine in gamma-ray light.
